channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Ever Given is Free (Again) From Suez Canal After Multimillion Dollar Payout
item.description: In the end, Ever Given’s owner and insurers paid the SCA an undisclosed amount—some Egyptian media reported $550 million and a “we’re sorry” tugboat—and the ship carrying goods worth hundreds of millions began its much-delayed journey to the Netherlands.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 8
item.description: (The Range Report)  Read: Some misunderstandings around the Sha’Carri Richardson saga. Experts say the challenge is a Hail Mary, but either way Trump began to send fundraising emails off of it immediately.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: What's Behind the Oil Squabble in the Gulf?
item.description: The UAE wants to increase its own production by more than the Saudi plan allows for, so talks fell apart and oil prices hit a six-year high earlier this week.     Looking ahead... The UAE’s strategy: The country is envisioning a future with more renewable energy and stricter climate-focused policies.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Employees in Iceland Start Working Four Days a Week
item.description: Both Spain and Japan are piloting a 32-hour work week over three years in response to changing perceptions of work during Covid.   Buffer, a social media software company, has let its 89 employees work four days a week since May 2020. Researchers found that a four-day week with the same pay improved workers’ well-being and productivity.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 7
item.description: (The Guardian) Read: Is it time to give up caffeine? The disaster is starting to ripple across South Florida’s sizzling real estate sector.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Nextdoor Announces SPAC With Expected $4.3 Billion Valuation
item.description: Like other social media companies, it uses a mix of machine-learning tech and human moderators to supervise discussion. Big picture: As the company scales and goes public, it'll be under greater scrutiny from investors to address racism and other toxic behaviors that have already surfaced on the app.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Subway Overhauls Menu in a Bid to Win Back Consumers
item.description: While fast-food rivals enjoyed booming demand for contactless pickups during Covid, Subway missed out on that opportunity since fewer than one in 10 Subway stores had a drive-thru.  But not too much innovation.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Pentagon Cancels Controversial JEDI Contract in Favor of Multi-Vendor Model
item.description: The Pentagon is replacing JEDI with the Joint Warfighter Cloud Capability (JWCC) project and opening up the contract to multiple potential vendors including Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet, and anyone else that can prove they’ve got the cloud computing chops to give the Defense Department an IT makeover. Cancel culture strikes again: The Pentagon said yesterday it’s scrapping its $10 billion JEDI cloud-computing contract with Microsoft and replacing it with another one that will require multiple vendors.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Employees in Iceland Start Working Four Days a Week
item.description: Researchers found that a four-day week with the same pay improved workers’ well-being and productivity.   Buffer, a social media software company, has let its 89 employees work four days a week since May 2020.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.description: The Pentagon is replacing JEDI with the Joint Warfighter Cloud Capability (JWCC) project and opening up the contract to multiple potential vendors including Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet, and anyone else that can prove they’ve got the cloud computing chops to give the Defense Department an IT makeover. item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Next Disruption in Finance Is Here (Yep, It Involves Crypto)
item.description: One Small Step for Trading, One Big Step for the Future of FinanceWell, it’s not that simple.  There’s more stuff going on there, but at a technical level, this means it’s a whole lot faster and cheaper to trade assets.  When people make trades on the blockchain, there are no intermediaries in sight—no brokers placing orders, no one rubber-stamping the trade in sight. A gradual, but still seismic, shift is taking place in the financial sector—aka the money biz.  All that takes time; up to two days for just one trade.  Version 2.0: Nothing Between You and Money That’s the normal-person way to describe our topic—disintermediation, or when financial institutions are scrubbed from trading like the videos of last Thursday’s karaoke night from your phone. The banks make money, you make money, other people get loans, everybody wins.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 6
item.description: (New Yorker) Read: Britney Spears’s conservatorship nightmare, by Ronan Farrow and Jia Tolentino.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Russia-linked Cybercrime Group Demands $70 Million Ransom
item.description: They also appeared to time the attack for Fourth of July weekend intentionally, knowing US office workers would be OOO. Looking ahead... Last month, it extorted $11 million from meat supplier JBS after forcing it to shut down its plants.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Chinese Regulators Kick Didi Off App Stores, Stop New User Sign-ups
item.description: Last week, Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing went public in one of the largest US IPOs of the past decade. This weekend, Chinese regulators stopped new users from signing up and ordered its removal from app stores.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: What's Next for Jeff Bezos?
item.description: PhilanthropyBezos has pledged $10 billion to climate-focused initiatives through the Bezos Earth Fund and gave $2 billion to increase access to education and address homelessness through the Bezos Day One Fund. SpaceBezos’s interest in space dates back to his teenage days, when the high school valedictorian told the Miami Herald he wanted to “build space hotels, amusement parks, and colonies for 2 million or 3 million people who would be in orbit.”  Fast forward to 2000, when Bezos founded his rocket company Blue Origin two years before Elon Musk would start SpaceX.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Short Week Ahead: July 6
item.description: Richard Branson will fly in a Virgin Galactic test flight to space on Sunday. Marvel’s Black Widow arrives Friday. Everything else:A Gossip Girl reboot comes to HBO Max on Thursday. And the National Spelling Bee (def a sport) final will be televised Thursday after getting canceled last year. Wimbledon continues through this week.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: What's Next for Jeff Bezos?
item.description: PhilanthropyBezos has pledged $10 billion to climate-focused initiatives through the Bezos Earth Fund and gave $2 billion to increase access to education and address homelessness through the Bezos Day One Fund. SpaceBezos’s interest in space dates back to his teenaged days, when the high school valedictorian told the Miami Herald he wanted to “build space hotels, amusement parks, and colonies for 2 million or 3 million people who would be in orbit.”  Fast forward to 2000, when Bezos founded his rocket company Blue Origin two years before Elon Musk would start SpaceX.

item.title: Companies Offer Lucrative Incentives to Lure Workers
item.description: Still, while incentives have become more popular they're only advertised in 4.2% of total job postings on Indeed. Plus, a bonus is a one-time commitment rather than an ongoing cost—such as a salary bump or additional PTO.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Help Definitely Wanted: The Restaurant Industry Faces A Labor Crunch
item.description: The restaurant business, inherently and pre-Covid, was a toxic workplace," North Carolina restaurant owner Patrick Whalen told CNN. But many former restaurant workers also found more stable jobs in other industries and didn’t look back.  After surveying over 2,800 food service workers, UC Berkeley Food Labor Research Center said the top three reasons that they’d leave their jobs are low wages and tips, lingering Covid-19 fears, and concerns of hostility from customers.  Where did they go?
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Exclusive: What’s the Job Market for College Students Like This Summer?
item.description: In a Morning Brew + Generation Lab poll, we asked 500 college students about their work plans for this summer and how they're feeling about it. After the unemployment rate for younger workers shot up to 32% last summer, the jobless rate for teens dropped to 9.6% this May, the lowest it's been since 1953, and stayed pretty steady in June at 9.9%.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Postings for HR Roles Jump 53% Above Pre-Pandemic Levels
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Diving into the Great Resignation and What It Means for American Workers
item.description: However, the main reason employees are quitting their jobs en masse, Harvard economics professor Jason Furman argues, is simpler: There are a record number of job openings in the US right now (9.3 million), and in any economy where lots of jobs are available, people leave their existing roles for greener pastures. A bunch of your coworkers are going to quit their jobs over the next few months—if you don’t leave before then.  In what’s been dubbed the “Great Resignation,” 4 million people, or 2.7% of US workers, quit their jobs in April. If they’re not pampered, they’re skedaddling.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Companies Offer Lucrative Incentives to Lure Workers
item.description: Still, while incentives are have become more popular they're only advertised in 4.2% of total job postings on Indeed. Plus, a bonus is a one-time commitment, rather than an ongoing cost—such as an income increase or additional PTO.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Help Definitely Wanted: The Restaurant Industry Faces A Labor Crunch
item.description: The restaurant business, inherently and pre-Covid, was a toxic workplace," North Carolina restaurant owner Patrick Whalen told CNN. But many former restaurant workers also found more stable jobs in other industries and didn’t look back.  After surveying over 2,800 food service workers, UC Berkeley Food Labor Research Center said the top three reasons that they’d leave their jobs are low wages and tips, lingering Covid-19 fears, and concerns of hostility from customers.  Where did they go?
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Postings for HR Roles Jump 53% Above Pre-Pandemic Levels
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Exclusive: What’s the Job Market for College Students Like This Summer?
item.description: In a Morning Brew + Generation Lab poll, we asked 500 college students about their work plans for this summer and how they were feeling about it. This was fascinating: 31% of students said their biggest concern when going to work this summer was understaffing at their employers, beating out worries over health and safety and working remotely. Most of the students having an easier time finding summer work are white.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Diving into the Great Resignation and What It Means for American Workers
item.description: However, the main reason employees are quitting their jobs en masse, Harvard economics professor Jason Furman argues, is simpler: There are a record number of job openings in the US right now (9.3 million), and in any economy where lots of jobs are available, people leave their existing roles for greener pastures.    In what’s been dubbed the “Great Resignation,” 4 million people, or 2.7% of US workers, quit their jobs in April. A bunch of your coworkers are going to quit their jobs over the next few months—if you don’t leave before then. If they’re not pampered, they’re skedaddling. Some say absolutely.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Money Matters: When to Pay Off Student Loans?
item.description: Submit your money woes here. If you think an investment will return more than your highest interest rate, you might want to start investing some money. Say your only debt is a student loan at 5% interest. If you think an investment will return more than 5% this year, investing might be a good shout. Should college grads start investing before paying off all student loans?
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 3
item.description: (The Atlantic)   Read: The three simple rules that underscore the danger of Delta. The positive test means she won’t be able to compete in the 100-meter race at the Tokyo Olympics, but could be available for the 4x100 meter relay.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Five Fast Firework Facts for the Fourth
item.description: Not helping: 90% of US fireworks are made in China, so logjams at ports over there mean a reduction or delay in getting supply over here. Massachusetts is the only state with a total ban on the sale of consumer fireworks. Thanks, Ben Affleck. 5.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Get to Know Amazon’s New CEO, Andy Jassy
item.description: Not long after, Jassy changed Amazon forever by coming up with and executing on the idea for Amazon’s cloud computing service, Amazon Web Services, which he currently leads.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: US Economy Adds 850,000 Jobs in June in Bullish Sign for Labor Market
item.description: The US economy added 850,000 jobs in June, marking the biggest monthly gain in almost a year and topping expectations. The 850,000 headline number represents a big improvement from May’s jobs report (+583,000 jobs) and April’s (+269,000). Economists hope that the increase in job seekers in June is a sign the labor crunch could smooth out by fall. Challenges remain, of course.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Get to Know Amazon’s New CEO, Andy Jassy
item.description: Not long after, Jassy changed Amazon forever by coming up with and executing on the idea for Amazon’s cloud computing service, Amazon Web Services, which he currently leads.
item.author: Jamie Wilde
